p: Phylogenetic analyses revealed that among persons with AHI/RHI, HIV-1 subtype A prevailed as the most frequent strain in circulation. HIV-1 subtypes C and G, and each of the variants of intersubtype recombinant mosaics (AD and A2D) were marginally present. Cumulatively, the frequency of CRFs was high. Some recombinants might indicate multiple infections [ 54] or independent transmission networks [ 55], but further analyses are essential to validate these. Consistent with previous molecular epidemiological assessments, we found subtypes A and D to be the most predominant strains that drive the epidemics in Kenya [ 16, 26, 32, 56] and East Africa [ 11, 28â€“ 31, 33]. Intersubtype AD remained the most common HIV-1 recombinant [ 16, 31, 33]. Great HIV diversity can foil accurate diagnosis, effective treatment and vaccine design [ 57].
